key_insight: Instead of treating a long image sequence as one huge stacked tensor, GriDiT factorizes the sequence into a grid of smaller spatial-temporal blocks and runs diffusion over that grid—dramatically reducing computation and memory while preserving temporal coherence.
problem_solved: Current generative models for long image sequences become computationally and memory-inefficient when frames are naively stacked; GriDiT addresses scalability and bottlenecks in generating long, high-resolution image sequences.
method: Factorize long image sequences into a grid of spatial-temporal blocks (tiles) rather than a single large tensor.
Apply diffusion modeling at the block level with lightweight cross-block conditioning to maintain global coherence while enabling parallelism.
Design training/inference mechanisms that reduce memory footprint and compute for long sequences, allowing scalable generation.
impact: Enables efficient generation of much longer and/or higher-resolution image sequences with lower compute and memory requirements, making research and production use of long-sequence diffusion models more practical.
visual_elements: Side-by-side diagram: traditional stacked-frame tensor vs. grid-factorized blocks (highlight memory savings).
Pipeline flowchart: block factorization → per-block diffusion → cross-block conditioning → stitched output.
Performance chart: compute/memory vs sequence length comparing baseline and GriDiT (log scale).
Qualitative montage: example long-sequence frames generated end-to-end to show temporal coherence.
paper_title: GriDiT: Factorized Grid-Based Diffusion for Efficient Long Image Sequence Generation
paper_authors: Snehal Singh Tomar, Alexandros Graikos, Arjun Krishna, Dimitris Samaras, Klaus Mueller
